com.guidewire.logging
Class Logger

java.lang.Object
  com.guidewire.logging.Logger
All Implemented Interfaces:
gw.util.ILogger
Direct Known Subclasses:
LoggerCategory
public class Logger
extends java.lang.Object
implements gw.util.ILogger

Use this class in conjunction with the LoggerFactory to use a class-based approach to logging. In this approach, you can configure logging on a class-by-class basis. The class-based approach is an alternative to the preferred technique which uses the LoggerFactory in combination with LoggerCategory. To use class-based logging, you would do the following:

  1. Configure a LoggerFactory.
  2. Configure the logger in the logger.properties file using the class name instead of the category name.
  3. Use the LoggerFactory to create a Logger instance.
  4. Send logging messages to your Logger instance.

The following example illustrates this method:


 private Logger _logger = null;  // set a class private variable
 _logger = LoggerFactory.getInstance().getLogger(MyJavaClassName.class); // initialize in your setup code
 _logger.info("Setting up logger ..."); // send logger messages

Logger offers several levels of logging, each level suggesting a different level of severity. Logs are considered "owned" by the system administrator so when choosing the level keep in mind what would be of interest to them. The following describes what each level is considered to mean or contain:

DEBUG
Used by developers solely to help diagnose a specific problem. Generally, and perhaps surprisingly, there is actually little call for debug info. See TRACE. It is possible for debug logging to have a negative impact on system performance due to the volume of logging.
FATAL
Deprecated. Use ERROR instead.
TRACE
Logs actions in the system such as "About to do something (inputs)" and "Completed something (results)". Trace logging should have no or minimal impact on system performance.
INFO
Announces the starting and stopping of something or progress of a long running task. Avoid using info() to simply report routine status. For example, the info message "User xyz logged in" is probably not very useful and serves only to clutter log files.
WARN
Indicates that the system has taken a default course of action that will result in something unexpected for the user. For example, too many unsuccessful logins will result in a user being locked out of the system, or an assignment cannot be found for a claim which results in a default assignment being made. These are both legal but possibly surprising to an end user.
ERROR
Indicates something has gone actually wrong and a user will see some sort of error message or state.

getLevel

setLevel

public void setLevel(org.apache.log4j.Level level)
Allows you to change the level of the logger. Use sparingly as setting a level higher or lower than what is defined in the logging.properties file can surprise administrators. Available logging levels: INFO, DEBUG, WARN, ERROR, TRACE. See Logger for more information.

isEnabledFor

public boolean isEnabledFor(org.apache.log4j.Level level)
Checks if the logger is enabled for the specified level.

Parameters:
level - minimum level to check for
Returns:
true if the logger is enabled for the specified or higher level, false otherwise.
